title: Great Glen Way Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Jim Barton / High point of the Great Glen Way
images.caption: High point of the Great Glen Way. The stone shelter marks the highest point, 422m, between Fort William and Inverness. Appropriately enough there is a great view of Loch Ness.

images.title: sylvia duckworth, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Corryfoyness croft and Cnoc an t'Saraidh in the distance.

images.title: Colin Smith / Great Glen Way
images.caption: A cleared section between Fort Augustus and Invermoriston which offers over the steep bracken-covered mountainside to Loch Ness below.

images.title: Douglas Nelson / Great Glen Way near Blackfold
images.caption: Great Glen Way near Blackfold

images.title: Colin Smith / Start of the Great Glen Way
images.caption: Start of the Great Glen Way Stone marking the Fort William terminal of the Great Glen Way, a 73 mile long path following the geological fault along the Glen to Inverness. This stone stands outside the Old Fort (seen in background) in Fort William.

images.title: Rob Burke / Great Glen Way
images.caption: These boards mark a viewpoint over Loch Ness on the Great Glen Way.

images.title: Iain Thompson / Great Glen Way at Loch Lochy
images.caption: Loch Lochy

images.title: Catherine Morgan / Inverness Castle and Great Glen Way finish post!
images.caption: Inverness Castle and Great Glen Way finish post^

description: Follow the Great Glen, running from Fort William in the west to Inverness in the east. The route is suitable for walkers and cyclists with a mountain bike or robust hybrid. The stunning trail follows the Caledonian Canal and the shores of Loch Lochy , Loch Oich and Loch Ness with the mountains of the Ben Nevis range making a splendid backdrop. The route also passes Fort Augustus and includes several woodland sections, most notably through Creag nan Eun Forest. The final section along the River Ness to the finish point at Inverness Castle is also noteworthy. The route is coincident with the Caledonia Way . This epic cycle route runs for 234 miles from Campbeltown to Inverness. It's a great way of continuing your cycling or walking in the area. The Great Glen Way is waymarked with a black hexagon thistle.
